div.p: he would sell him – some of those gave me to understand by signs that they would not sell their horses & others shook their Heads, & Mr Henry had been often bargaining with the Gros Ventres, in my absence for the very horses he had refused that very morning but the bargain was immediately at an end when I assured him of his error[.] We arrived at the Shawyens Camps some short while before sun set – Where we were all received with cordial amity – & having accompanied the Borgne's brother to where the former resided – & being informed of the dignity of the strangers the Borgne received them with tokens of more respect than the rest of the Gros Ventres paid them[.]

The Borgne asked us our liberty to go & recommend good amity between the nations that they should not steal nor quarrel with one another but be as firm in their friendship as one nation – having got upon his famous horse he passed like lightening throught the middle of the Camp, which was as throng with people & horses as a market-place, haranging them in friendly terms – to have good understanding among them, & when he came down from his horse at the Door of the Lodge, he put the bridle of his horse into Mr Chaboillez's hand[.] Mr C. being sensible of the Borgne's generosity he gave him his bundle of goods untied[.] The Borgne appeared much satisfied the goods, tho' I Knew that at another time double the quantity would allure him to part with his horse, but to shew his consequence to the Shawyens, he launched out on the many tokens of respect confered on him by the White people & that these Chiefs came from the Red River purposely to see him & that he was sorry that he had not a good horse to give to Each[.] Mr Henry began to despaire of getting a horse to his taste – & I myself enquired of the Borgne if he had
